cleaned_text: Pharmaceutical industry The pharmaceutical industry discovers, develops, produces, and markets pharmaceutical [drugs](/wiki/Drug) for the use as [medications](/wiki/Medication) to be administered to [patients](/wiki/Patient) (or self-administered), with the aim to [cure](/wiki/Cure) or [symptoms](/wiki/Symptom). may deal in [generic](/wiki/Generic_drug) or [brand](/wiki/Brand) medications and medical devices. They are subject to a [variety of laws](/wiki/Legal_drug_trade) and regulations that govern the [patenting](/wiki/Patent), testing, safety, efficacy using drug testing and [marketing of drugs](/wiki/Legal_drug_trade). The global pharmaceuticals market produced treatments worth $1,228.45 billion in 2020 and showed a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 1.8%. [[3]](#cite_note-3) History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=1)] first synthetic drugs[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=2)] The modern era of pharmaceutical industry began with local apothecaries that expanded from their traditional role of distributing botanical drugs such as [morphine](/wiki/Morphine) and [quinine](/wiki/Quinine) to wholesale manufacture in the mid-1800s, and from discoveries resulting from applied research. Intentional [drug discovery](/wiki/Drug_discovery) from plants began with the isolation between 1803 and 1805 of [morphine](/wiki/Morphine) - an analgesic and sleep-inducing agent - from opium by the German apothecary assistant [Friedrich Sertürner](/wiki/Friedrich_Sert%C3%BCrner), who named this compound after the Greek god of dreams, [Morpheus](/wiki/Morpheus_(mythology)). [[4]](#cite_note-4) By the late 1880s, German dye manufacturers had perfected the purification of individual [organic compounds](/wiki/Organic_compounds) from tar and other mineral sources and had also established rudimentary methods in [organic chemical synthesis](/wiki/Organic_synthesis). [[5]](#cite_note-5) The development of synthetic chemical methods allowed scientists to systematically vary the structure of chemical substances, and growth in the emerging science of [pharmacology](/wiki/Pharmacology) expanded their ability to evaluate the biological effects of these structural changes. Epinephrine, norepinephrine, and amphetamine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=3)] By the 1890s, the profound effect of [adrenal](/wiki/Adrenal_gland) extracts on many different tissue types had been discovered, setting off a search both for the mechanism of chemical signalling and efforts to exploit these observations for the development of new drugs. The blood pressure raising and vasoconstrictive effects of adrenal extracts were of particular interest to surgeons as [hemostatic](/wiki/Hemostatic) agents and as treatment for shock, and a number of companies developed products based on adrenal extracts containing varying purities of the active substance. In 1897, [John Abel](/wiki/John_Jacob_Abel) of [Johns Hopkins University](/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_School_of_Medicine) identified the active principle as [epinephrine](/wiki/Adrenaline), which he isolated in an impure state as the sulfate salt. Industrial chemist [Jkichi Takamine](/wiki/Takamine_J%C5%8Dkichi) later developed a method for obtaining epinephrine in a pure state, and licensed the technology to [Parke-Davis](/wiki/Parke-Davis). Parke-Davis marketed epinephrine under the trade name [Adrenalin](/wiki/Epinephrine_(medication)). Injected epinephrine proved to be especially efficacious for the acute treatment of [asthma](/wiki/Asthma) attacks, and an inhaled version was sold in the United States until 2011 ( [Primatene Mist](/wiki/Primatene_Mist)). [[6]](#cite_note-Sneader2005-6) [[7]](#cite_note-Rasmussen_2006_288-323-7) By 1929 epinephrine had been formulated into an inhaler for use in the treatment of nasal congestion. While highly effective, the requirement for injection limited the use of epinephrine[ [clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify)] and orally active derivatives were sought. A structurally similar compound, [ephedrine](/wiki/Ephedrine), was identified by Japanese chemists in the Ma Huang plant and marketed by [Eli Lilly](/wiki/Eli_Lilly_and_Company) as an oral treatment for asthma. Following the work of [Henry Dale](/wiki/Henry_Hallett_Dale) and [George Barger](/wiki/George_Barger) at [Burroughs-Wellcome](/wiki/Burroughs_Wellcome_Fund), academic chemist [Gordon Alles](/wiki/Gordon_Alles) synthesized amphetamine and tested it in asthma patients in 1929. The drug proved to have only modest anti-asthma effects but produced sensations of exhilaration and palpitations. Amphetamine was developed by [Smith, Kline and French](/wiki/Smith,_Kline_and_French) as a nasal decongestant under the trade name [Benzedrine Inhaler.](/wiki/Benzedrine) Amphetamine was eventually developed for the treatment of [narcolepsy](/wiki/Narcolepsy), [post-encephalitic parkinsonism](/wiki/Post-encephalitic_parkinsonism), and mood elevation in depression and other psychiatric indications. It received approval as a New and Nonofficial Remedy from the [American Medical Association](/wiki/American_Medical_Association) for these uses in 1937, [[8]](#cite_note-8) and remained in common use for depression until the development of [tricyclic antidepressants](/wiki/Tricyclic_antidepressants) in the 1960s. [[7]](#cite_note-Rasmussen_2006_288-323-7) Discovery and development of the barbiturates[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=4)] In 1903, [Hermann Emil Fischer](/wiki/Hermann_Emil_Fischer) and [Joseph von Mering](/wiki/Joseph_von_Mering) disclosed their discovery that diethylbarbituric acid, formed from the reaction of diethylmalonic acid, phosphorus oxychloride and urea, induces sleep in dogs. The discovery was patented and licensed to [Bayer pharmaceuticals](/wiki/Bayer_pharmaceuticals), which marketed the compound under the trade name [Veronal](/wiki/Veronal) as a sleep aid beginning in 1904. Systematic investigations of the effect of structural changes on potency and duration of action led to the discovery of [phenobarbital](/wiki/Phenobarbital) at Bayer in 1911 and the discovery of its potent anti-epileptic activity in 1912. Phenobarbital was among the most widely used drugs for the treatment of [epilepsy](/wiki/Epilepsy) through the 1970s, and as of 2014, remains on the World Health Organizations list of essential medications. [[9]](#cite_note-9) [[10]](#cite_note-10) The 1950s and 1960s saw increased awareness of the addictive properties and abuse potential of barbiturates and amphetamines and led to increasing restrictions on their use and growing government oversight of prescribers. Today, amphetamine is largely restricted to use in the treatment of [attention deficit disorder](/wiki/Attention_deficit_disorder) and phenobarbital in the treatment of [epilepsy](/wiki/Epilepsy). Dozens of other benzodiazepines have been developed and are in use, some of the more popular drugs being [diazepam](/wiki/Diazepam) (Valium), [alprazolam](/wiki/Alprazolam) (Xanax), [clonazepam](/wiki/Clonazepam) (Klonopin), and [lorazepam](/wiki/Lorazepam) (Ativan). their far superior safety and therapeutic properties, benzodiazepines have largely replaced the use of barbiturates in medicine, except in certain special cases. When it was later discovered that benzodiazepines, like barbiturates, significantly lose their effectiveness and can have serious side effects when taken long-term, [Heather Ashton](/wiki/Heather_Ashton) researched benzodiazepine dependence and developed a protocol to discontinue their use. Insulin[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=5)] A series of experiments performed from the late 1800s to the early 1900s revealed that [diabetes](/wiki/Diabetes) is caused by the absence of a substance normally produced by the pancreas. In 1869, [Oskar Minkowski](/wiki/Oskar_Minkowski) and [Joseph von Mering](/wiki/Joseph_von_Mering) found that diabetes could be induced in dogs by surgical removal of the pancreas. In 1921, Canadian professor [Frederick Banting](/wiki/Frederick_Banting) and his student Charles Best repeated this study and found that injections of pancreatic extract reversed the symptoms produced by pancreas removal. Soon, the extract was demonstrated to work in people, but development of insulin therapy as a routine medical procedure was delayed by difficulties in producing the material in sufficient quantity and with reproducible purity. The researchers sought assistance from industrial collaborators at Eli Lilly and Co. based on the company's experience with large scale purification of biological materials. Chemist [George B. Walden](/wiki/George_B._Walden) of Eli Lilly and Company found that careful adjustment of the pH of the extract allowed a relatively pure grade of insulin to be produced. Under pressure from Toronto University and a potential patent challenge by academic scientists who had independently developed a similar purification method, an agreement was reached for non-exclusive production of insulin by multiple companies. Prior to the discovery and widespread availability of insulin therapy the life expectancy of diabetics was only a few months. [[13]](#cite_note-13) Early anti-infective research: Salvarsan, Prontosil, Penicillin and vaccines[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=6)] The development of drugs for the treatment of infectious diseases was a major focus of early research and development efforts; in 1900, pneumonia, tuberculosis, and diarrhea were the three leading causes of death in the United States and mortality in the first year of life exceeded 10%. [[14]](#cite_note-14) [[15]](#cite_note-15)[ [failed verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability)] In 1911 [arsphenamine](/wiki/Arsphenamine), anti-infective drug, was developed by [Paul Ehrlich](/wiki/Paul_Ehrlich) and chemist Alfred Bertheim of the Institute of Experimental Therapy in Berlin. The drug was given the commercial name Salvarsan. [[16]](#cite_note-16) Ehrlich, noting both the general toxicity of [arsenic](/wiki/Arsenic) and the selective absorption of certain dyes by bacteria, hypothesized that an arsenic-containing dye with similar selective absorption properties could be used to treat bacterial infections. Arsphenamine was prepared as part of a campaign to synthesize a series of such compounds, and was found to exhibit partially selective toxicity. Arsphenamine proved to be the first effective treatment for [syphilis](/wiki/Syphilis), a disease untl then had been incurable and led inexorably to severe skin ulceration, neurological damage, and death. [[17]](#cite_note-17) Ehrlich's approach of systematically varying the chemical structure of synthetic compounds and measuring the effects of these changes on biological activity was pursued broadly by industrial scientists, including [Bayer](/wiki/Bayer) scientists Josef Klarer, Fritz Mietzsch, and [Gerhard Domagk](/wiki/Gerhard_Domagk). This work, also based on the testing of compounds available from the German dye industry, led to the development of [Prontosil](/wiki/Prontosil), the first representative of the [sulfonamide](/wiki/Sulfonamide) class of [antibiotics](/wiki/Antibiotics). Compared to arsphenamine, the sulfonamides had a broader spectrum of activity and were far less toxic, rendering them useful for infections caused by pathogens such as [streptococci](/wiki/Streptococci). [[18]](#cite_note-18) In 1939, Domagk received the [Nobel Prize in Medicine](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine) for this discovery. [[19]](#cite_note-19) [[20]](#cite_note-20) Nonetheless, the dramatic decrease in deaths from infectious diseases that occurred prior to [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II) was primarily the result of improved public health measures such as clean water and less crowded housing, and the impact of anti-infective drugs and vaccines was significant mainly after World War II. [[21]](#cite_note-21) [[22]](#cite_note-Klein_2012_167-22) In 1928, [Alexander Fleming](/wiki/Alexander_Fleming) discovered the antibacterial effects of [penicillin](/wiki/Penicillin), but its exploitation for the treatment of human disease awaited the development of methods for its large scale production and purification. These were developed by a U.S. and British government-led consortium of pharmaceutical companies during the world war. [[23]](#cite_note-JParas-23) There was early progress toward the development of vaccines throughout this period, primarily in the form of academic and government-funded basic research directed toward the identification of the pathogens responsible for common communicable diseases. In 1885, [Louis vaccine](/wiki/Rabies_vaccine). The first [diphtheria vaccines](/wiki/Diphtheria_vaccine) were produced in 1914 from a mixture of [diphtheria toxin](/wiki/Diphtheria_toxin) and [antitoxin](/wiki/Diphtheria_antitoxin) (produced from the serum of an inoculated animal), but the safety of the inoculation was marginal and it was not widely used. The United States recorded 206,000 cases of diphtheria in 1921, resulting in 15,520 deaths. In 1923, parallel efforts by [Gaston Ramon](/wiki/Gaston_Ramon) at the Pasteur Institute and [Alexander Glenny](/wiki/Alexander_Glenny) at the Wellcome Research Laboratories (later part of [GlaxoSmithKline](/wiki/GlaxoSmithKline)) led to the discovery that a safer vaccine could be produced by treating diphtheria toxin with [formaldehyde](/wiki/Formaldehyde). [[24]](#cite_note-24) In 1944, [Maurice Hilleman](/wiki/Maurice_Hilleman) of Squibb Pharmaceuticals developed the first [vaccine against Japanese Encephalitis](/wiki/Japanese_encephalitis_vaccine). [[25]](#cite_note-25) Hilleman later moved to [Merck](/wiki/Merck_and_Company), where he played a key role in the development of vaccines against early industry regulation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=7)] Prior to the 20th century, drugs were generally produced by small scale manufacturers with little regulatory control over manufacturing or claims of safety and efficacy. To the extent that such laws did exist, enforcement was lax. In the United States, increased regulation of vaccines and other biological drugs was spurred by tetanus outbreaks and deaths caused by the distribution of contaminated smallpox vaccine and diphtheria antitoxin. [[26]](#cite_note-26) The Biologics Control Act of 1902 required that federal government grant premarket approval for every biological drug and for the process and facility producing such drugs. This was followed in 1906 by the [Pure Food and Drugs Act](/wiki/Pure_Food_and_Drugs_Act), which forbade the interstate distribution of adulterated or misbranded foods and drugs. A drug was considered misbranded if it contained alcohol, morphine, opium, cocaine, or any of several other potentially dangerous or addictive drugs, and if its label failed to indicate the quantity or proportion of such drugs. The government's attempts to use the law to prosecute manufacturers for making unsupported claims of efficacy were undercut by a Supreme Court ruling restricting the federal government's enforcement powers to cases of incorrect specification of the drug's ingredients. [[27]](#cite_note-27) In 1937 over 100 people died after ingesting " [Elixir Sulfanilamide](/wiki/Elixir_Sulfanilamide)" manufactured by S.E. Massengill Company of Tennessee. The product was formulated in [diethylene glycol](/wiki/Diethylene_glycol), a highly toxic solvent that is now widely used as antifreeze. [[28]](#cite_note-28) Under the laws extant at that time, prosecution of the manufacturer was possible only under the technicality that the product had been called an "elixir", which literally implied a solution in ethanol. In response to this episode, the U.S. Congress passed [the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act of 1938](/wiki/Federal_Food,_Drug,_and_Cosmetic_Act), which for the first time required pre-market demonstration of safety before a drug could be sold, and explicitly prohibited false therapeutic claims. [[29]](#cite_note-29) The post-war years, 1945-1970[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=8)] Further advances in anti-infective research[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=9)] The aftermath of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II) saw an explosion in the discovery of new classes of antibacterial drugs [[30]](#cite_note-30) including the [cephalosporins](/wiki/Cephalosporins) (developed by Eli Lilly based on the seminal work of [Giuseppe Brotzu](/wiki/Giuseppe_Brotzu) and [Edward Abraham](/wiki/Edward_Abraham)), [[31]](#cite_note-31) laboratory [[33]](#cite_note-Kingston_W_441-62-33)), the tetracyclines [[34]](#cite_note-34) (discovered at Lederle Laboratories, now a part of [Pfizer](/wiki/Pfizer)), erythromycin (discovered at Eli Lilly and Co.) [[35]](#cite_note-35) and their extension to an increasingly wide range of bacterial pathogens. Streptomycin, discovered during a Merck-funded research program in Selman Waksman's laboratory at Rutgers in 1943, became the first effective treatment for tuberculosis. At the time of its discovery, sanitoriums for the isolation of tuberculosis-infected people were an ubiquitous feature of cities in developed countries, with 50% dying within 5 years of admission. [[33]](#cite_note-Kingston_W_441-62-33) [[36]](#cite_note-36) A Federal Trade Commission report issued in 1958 attempted to quantify the effect of antibiotic development on American public health. The report found that over the period 1946-1955, there was a 42% drop in the incidence of diseases for which antibiotics were effective and only a 20% drop in those for which antibiotics were not effective. The report concluded that "it appears that the use of antibiotics, early diagnosis, and other factors have limited the epidemic spread and thus the number of these diseases which have occurred". The study further examined mortality rates for eight common diseases for which antibiotics offered effective therapy (syphilis, tuberculosis, dysentery, scarlet fever, whooping cough, meningococcal infections, and pneumonia), and found a 56% decline over the same period. [[37]](#cite_note-37) Notable among these was a 75% decline in deaths due to tuberculosis. [[38]](#cite_note-38) During the years 1940-1955, the rate of decline in the U.S. [death rate](/wiki/Death_rate) accelerated from 2% per year to 8% per year, then returned to the historical rate of 2% per year. The dramatic decline in the immediate post-war years has been attributed to the rapid development of new treatments and vaccines for infectious disease that occurred during these years. [[40]](#cite_note-www.nber.org-40) [[22]](#cite_note-Klein_2012_167-22) Vaccine development continued to accelerate, with the most notable achievement of the period being [Jonas Salk](/wiki/Jonas_Salk)'s 1954 development of the polio vaccine under the funding of the non-profit National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The vaccine process was never patented but was instead given to pharmaceutical companies to manufacture as a low-cost [generic](/wiki/Generic_drug). In 1960 Maurice Hilleman of [Merck Sharp & Dohme](/wiki/Merck_Sharp_%26_Dohme) identified the [SV40](/wiki/SV40) virus, which was later shown to cause tumors in many mammalian species. It was later determined that SV40 was present as a contaminant in polio vaccine lots that had been administered to 90% of the children in the United States. [[41]](#cite_note-41) [[42]](#cite_note-42) The contamination appears to have originated both in the original cell stock and in monkey tissue used for production. In 2004 the United States Cancer Institute announced that it had concluded that SV40 is not associated with cancer in people. [[43]](#cite_note-43) Other notable new vaccines of the period include those for measles (1962, John Franklin Enders of Children's Medical Center Boston, later refined by Maurice Hilleman at Merck), Rubella (1969, Hilleman, Merck) and mumps (1967, syndrome, measles, and mumps all fell by >95% in the immediate aftermath of widespread vaccination. [[45]](#cite_note-45) The first 20 years of licensed [measles vaccination](/wiki/Measles_vaccine) in the U.S. prevented an estimated 52 million cases of the disease, 17,400 cases of [mental retardation](/wiki/Mental_retardation), and 5,200 deaths. [[46]](#cite_note-46) Development and marketing of antihypertensive drugs[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=10)] Hypertension and Prior to 1940 approximately 23% of all deaths among persons over age 50 were attributed to hypertension. Severe cases of hypertension were treated by surgery. [[57]](#cite_note-57) Early developments in the field of treating hypertension included quaternary ammonium ion sympathetic nervous system blocking agents, but these compounds were never widely used due to their severe side effects, because the long-term health consequences of high blood pressure had not yet been established, and because they had to be administered by injection. In 1952 researchers at Ciba discovered the first orally available vasodilator, hydralazine. [[58]](#cite_note-58) A major shortcoming of hydralazine monotherapy was that it lost its effectiveness over time ( [tachyphylaxis](/wiki/Tachyphylaxis)). In the mid-1950s Karl H. Beyer, James M. Sprague, John E. Baer, and Frederick C. Novello of [Merck and Co.](/wiki/Merck_and_Co.) discovered and developed [chlorothiazide](/wiki/Chlorothiazide), which remains the most widely used antihypertensive drug today. [[59]](#cite_note-59) This development was associated with a substantial decline in the mortality rate among people with hypertension. [[60]](#cite_note-60) The inventors were recognized by a Public Health [Lasker Award](/wiki/Lasker_Award) in 1975 for "the saving of untold thousands of lives and the alleviation of the suffering of millions of victims of hypertension". [[61]](#cite_note-61) A 2009 Cochrane review concluded that thiazide antihypertensive drugs reduce the risk of death ( [RR](/wiki/Relative_risk) 0.89), stroke (RR 0.63), coronary heart disease (RR 0.84), and cardiovascular events (RR 0.70) in people with high blood pressure. [[62]](#cite_note-62) In the ensuring years other classes of antihypertensive drug were developed and found wide acceptance in combination therapy, including loop blockers](/wiki/Angiotensin_receptor_blockers). ACE inhibitors reduce the risk of new onset kidney disease [RR 0.71] and death [RR 0.84] in diabetic patients, irrespective of whether they have hypertension. [[65]](#cite_note-65) Oral Contraceptives[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=11)] Prior to the Second World war, birth control was prohibited in many countries, and in the United States even the discussion of contraceptive methods sometimes led to prosecution under [Comstock laws](/wiki/Comstock_laws). The history of the development of oral contraceptives is thus closely tied to the [birth control movement](/wiki/Birth_control_movement_in_the_United_States) and the efforts of activists [Margaret Sanger](/wiki/Margaret_Sanger), [Mary Dennett](/wiki/Mary_Dennett), and [Emma Goldman](/wiki/Emma_Goldman). Based on fundamental research performed by [Gregory Pincus](/wiki/Gregory_Pincus) and synthetic methods for progesterone developed by [Carl Djerassi](/wiki/Carl_Djerassi) at [Syntex](/wiki/Syntex) and by [Frank Colton](/wiki/Frank_Colton) at [G.D. Searle & Co.](/wiki/G.D._Searle_%26_Co.), the first oral contraceptive, [Enovid](/wiki/Enovid), was developed by E.D. Searle and Co. and approved by the FDA in 1960. The original formulation incorporated vastly excessive doses of hormones, and caused severe side effects. Nonetheless, by 1962, 1.2 million American women were on the pill, and by 1965 the number had increased to 6.5 million. [[66]](#cite_note-66) [[67]](#cite_note-67) [[68]](#cite_note-68) [[69]](#cite_note-69) The availability of a convenient form of temporary contraceptive led to dramatic changes in social mores including expanding the range of lifestyle options available to women, reducing the reliance of women on men for contraceptive practice, encouraging the delay of marriage, and increasing pre-marital co-habitation. [[70]](#cite_note-70) Thalidomide and the Kefauver-Harris Amendments[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=12)] In the U.S., a push for revisions of the FD&C Act emerged from Congressional hearings led by Senator [Estes Kefauver](/wiki/Estes_Kefauver) of Tennessee in 1959. The hearings covered a wide range of policy issues, including advertising abuses, questionable efficacy of drugs, and the need for greater regulation of the industry. While momentum for new legislation temporarily flagged under extended debate, a new tragedy emerged that underscored the need for more comprehensive regulation and provided the driving force for the passage of new laws. On 12 September 1960, an American licensee, the William S. Merrell Company of Cincinnati, submitted a new drug application for Kevadon ( [thalidomide](/wiki/Thalidomide)), a sedative that had been marketed in Europe since 1956. The FDA medical officer in charge of reviewing the compound, [Frances Kelsey](/wiki/Frances_Oldham_Kelsey), believed that the data supporting the safety of thalidomide was incomplete. The firm continued to pressure Kelsey and the FDA to approve the application until November 1961, when the drug was pulled off the German market because of its association with grave congenital abnormalities. Several thousand newborns in Europe and elsewhere suffered the [teratogenic](/wiki/Teratogenic) effects of thalidomide. Without approval from the FDA, the firm distributed Kevadon to over 1,000 physicians there under the guise of investigational use. Over 20,000 Americans received thalidomide in this "study," including 624 pregnant patients, and about 17 known newborns suffered the effects of the drug.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] The [thalidomide](/wiki/Thalidomide) tragedy resurrected Kefauver's bill to enhance drug regulation that had stalled in Congress, and the [Kefauver-Harris Amendment](/wiki/Kefauver-Harris_Amendment) became law on 10 October 1962. Manufacturers henceforth had to prove to FDA that their drugs were effective as well as safe before they could go on the US market. The FDA received authority to regulate advertising of prescription drugs and to establish [good manufacturing practices](/wiki/Good_manufacturing_practices). The law required that all drugs introduced between 1938 and 1962 had to be effective. An FDA - National Academy of Sciences collaborative study showed that nearly 40 percent of these products were not effective. A similarly comprehensive study of over-the-counter products began ten years later. [[71]](#cite_note-71) 1970-1990s[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=13)] Statins[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=14)] In 1971, Akira Endo, a working for the pharmaceutical company Sankyo, identified mevastatin (ML-236B), a molecule produced by the fungus Penicillium citrinum, as an inhibitor of HMG-CoA reductase, a critical enzyme used by the body to produce cholesterol. [Animal trials](/wiki/Animal_testing) showed very good inhibitory effect as in [clinical trials](/wiki/Clinical_trial), however a long-term study in dogs found toxic effects at higher doses and as a result mevastatin was believed to be too toxic for human use. Mevastatin was never marketed, because of its adverse effects of tumors, muscle deterioration, and sometimes death in laboratory dogs. [P. Roy Vagelos](/wiki/P._Roy_Vagelos), chief scientist and later CEO of [Merck & Co](/wiki/Merck_%26_Co), was interested, and made several trips to Japan starting in 1975. By 1978, Merck had isolated [lovastatin](/wiki/Lovastatin) (mevinolin, MK803) from the fungus [Aspergillus 1987 as Mevacor. [[72]](#cite_note-Tobert_2003-72) [[73]](#cite_note-Endo_1992-73) [[74]](#cite_note-Endo_2004-74) In April 1994, the results of a Merck-sponsored study, the [Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study](/wiki/Scandinavian_Simvastatin_Survival_Study), were announced. Researchers tested [simvastatin](/wiki/Simvastatin), later sold by Merck as Zocor, on 4,444 patients with high cholesterol and heart disease. After five years, the study concluded the patients saw a 35% reduction in their cholesterol, and their chances of dying of a heart attack were reduced by 42%. [[75]](#cite_note-4S-75) In 1995, Zocor and Mevacor both made Merck over US$1 billion. Endo was awarded the 2006 [Japan Prize](/wiki/Japan_Prize), and the [Lasker-DeBakey Clinical Medical Research Award](/wiki/Lasker-DeBakey_Clinical_Medical_Research_Award) in 2008. The [biotech](/wiki/Biotechnology) subsector, animal health and the Chinese pharmaceutical sector have also grown substantially. On the organisational side, big international pharma corporations have experienced a substantial decline of their value share. Also, the core generic sector (substitutions for off-patent brands) has been downvalued due to competition. [[78]](#cite_note-78) Torreya estimated the pharmaceutical industry to have a market valuation of USD 7.03 trillion by February 2021 from which USD 6.1 trillion is the value of the publicly-traded companies. Small Molecules modality had 58.2% of the valuation share down from 84.6% in 2003. Biologics was up at 30.5% from 14.5%. The valuation share of chinese Pharma grew from 2003 to 2021 from 1% to 12% overtaking Switzerland who is now ranked number 3 with 7.7%. The United States had still by far the most valued pharmaceutical industry with 40% of global valuation. [[79]](#cite_note-79) Impact of Mergers and Acquisitions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=16)] A 2022 article articulated this notion succinctly by saying "In the business of drug development, deals can be just as important as scientific breakthroughs", typically referred to as pharmaceutical M&A (for mergers and acquisitions). [[80]](#cite_note-:0-80) It highlighted that some of the most impactful of the remedies of the early 21st Century were only made possible through M&A activities, specifically noting [Keytruda](/wiki/Keytruda) and [Humira](/wiki/Humira). [[80]](#cite_note-:0-80) Research and development[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=17)] Drug discovery is the process by which potential [drugs](/wiki/Medications) are discovered or designed. In the past, most drugs have been discovered either by isolating the active ingredient from traditional remedies or by [serendipitous](/wiki/Serendipity) discovery. Modern [biotechnology](/wiki/Biotechnology) often focuses on understanding the [metabolic pathways](/wiki/Metabolic_pathway) related to a [disease](/wiki/Disease) state or [pathogen](/wiki/Pathogen), and manipulating these pathways using [molecular biology](/wiki/Molecular_biology) or [biochemistry](/wiki/Biochemistry). A great deal of early-stage drug discovery has traditionally been carried out by universities and research institutions. Drug development refers to activities undertaken after a compound is identified as a potential drug in order to establish its suitability as a medication. Objectives of drug development are to determine appropriate [formulation](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_formulation) and [dosing](/wiki/Dosing), as well as to establish [safety](/wiki/Drug_safety). Research in these areas generally includes a combination of [in vitro](/wiki/In_vitro) studies, [in vivo](/wiki/In_vivo) studies, and [clinical trials](/wiki/Clinical_trials). The cost of late stage development has meant it is usually done by the larger pharmaceutical companies. [[81]](#cite_note-81) The pharmaceuticals and biotechnology industry spends more than 15% of its net sales for Research & Development which is in comparison with other industries by far the highest share. [[82]](#cite_note-82) Often, large multinational corporations exhibit [vertical integration](/wiki/Vertical_integration), participating in a broad range of drug discovery and development, manufacturing and quality control, marketing, sales, and distribution. Smaller organizations, on the other hand, often focus on a specific aspect such as discovering drug candidates or developing formulations. Often, collaborative agreements between research organizations and large pharmaceutical companies are formed to explore the potential of new drug substances. More recently, multi-nationals are increasingly relying on [contract research organizations](/wiki/Contract_research_organization) to manage drug development. [[83]](#cite_note-83) The cost of innovation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=18)] [Drug](/wiki/Medication) discovery and development are very expensive; of all compounds investigated for use in humans only a small fraction are eventually [approved](/wiki/Approved_drugs) in most nations by government-appointed medical institutions or boards, who have to approve new [drugs](/wiki/Medication) before they can be marketed in those countries. On the other hand, there were only 18 approvals in total in 2007 and 22 back in 2006. Since 2001, the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research has averaged 22.9 approvals a year. Drugs which fail part-way through this process often incur large costs, while generating no revenue in return. If the cost of these failed drugs is taken into account, the cost of developing a successful new drug ( [new chemical entity](/wiki/New_chemical_entity), or NCE), has been estimated at US$1.3 billion [[85]](#cite_note-85) (not including [marketing expenses](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_marketing)). Product approval[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry&action=edit§ion=19)] In the United States, new pharmaceutical products must be approved by the [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration_(United_States)) (FDA) as being both safe and effective. This process generally involves submission of an [Investigational New Drug](/wiki/Investigational_New_Drug) filing with sufficient pre-clinical data to support proceeding with human trials. Following IND approval, three phases of progressively larger human clinical trials may be conducted. Phase I generally studies [toxicity](/wiki/Toxicity) using healthy volunteers. Phase II can include [pharmacokinetics](/wiki/Pharmacokinetics) and [dosing](/wiki/Dosing) in patients, and Phase III is a very large study of efficacy in the intended patient population. Following the successful completion of phase III testing, a [New Drug Application](/wiki/New_Drug_Application) is submitted to the FDA. The FDA reviews the data and if the product is seen as having a positive benefit-risk assessment, approval to market the product in the US is granted. In certain instances, its indication may need to be limited to particular patient groups, and in others the substance is withdrawn from the market completely. Then it is the [National Institute for Health and Care Excellence](/wiki/National_Institute_for_Health_and_Care_Excellence) (NICE), for England and Wales, who decides if and how the [National Health Service](/wiki/National_Health_Service) (NHS) will allow (in the sense of paying for) their use.
